entry.title: Ai-Khanoum (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that artefacts from Ai-Khanoum, a Hellenistic city rediscovered by the King of Afghanistan in 1961, include a "remarkable" disc (pictured) displaying "hybrid Greek and Oriental imagery"?

entry.title: Skyrush (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that it takes about five hours to inspect Skyrush every morning?

entry.title: 2010 Sudanese general election in Jonglei (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that after the results of the 2010 Sudanese general election in Jonglei were announced, two disgruntled candidates launched armed insurgencies?

entry.title: Samuel Green (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Samuel Green printed the Eliot Indian Bible, the first Bible printed in British America, in 1663?

entry.title: syphilis in sub-Saharan Africa (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a lack of screening for pregnant women with syphilis in sub-Saharan Africa is associated with increased infant mortality?

entry.title: Kléber Dupuy (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in the 1960s Kléber Dupuy campaigned to rehabilitate the reputation of Philippe Pétain, against whose Vichy regime he had fought as a member of the French Resistance?

entry.title: placed without their consent during the 1960s and 1970s (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that thousands of Greenlandic women and girls had intrauterine devices placed without their consent during the 1960s and 1970s?

entry.title: a Phoenix radio station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that by the time he became Governor of Arizona, John Howard Pyle's appearances on a Phoenix radio station made him "as familiar in Arizona homes as the family radio"?
